title: 112_s2163
content:
The "Kidney Disease Equitable Access, Prevention, and Research Act of 2012" aims to provide equitable access to care for individuals with kidney disease and support research to improve access to high-quality kidney care. It includes provisions for improving access to care, providing choice in primary insurer, and protecting individuals with kidney failure from unfair practices. The "Kidney Disease Equitable Access, Prevention, and Research Act of 2012" includes provisions for understanding kidney disease progression in minority populations, recommendations on dialysis quality research, a GAO study on transportation barriers, improving access to Medicare kidney disease education, and enhancing access to care through improvements in the initial survey process for renal dialysis facilities. The Social Security Act is amended to allow the Secretary to accept State licensure survey results for determining Federal certification of compliance for renal dialysis facilities. States may waive reimbursement for conducting the initial survey. The Secretary can accept State licensure survey results for Federal certification of renal dialysis facilities and may assess fees for initial Medicare surveys. The Secretary can assess fees for initial surveys of renal dialysis facilities to cover costs, with fees collected based on facility survey costs. These fees are collected by the Secretary and used only for conducting initial surveys as specified in appropriations Acts. The Secretary can assess fees for initial surveys of renal dialysis facilities to cover costs, with fees collected based on facility survey costs. These fees are authorized to remain available until expended upon request of the Secretary. SEC. 102. PROVIDING CHOICE IN PRIMARY INSURER. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Social Security Act regarding patient choice in healthcare services, with changes effective from January 1, 2013. The text chunk clarifies that the Medicare Secondary Payer rules under the Social Security Act apply to qualified health plans, extending the coordinating period for individuals with kidney failure to 42 months. SEC. 103. PROTECTING INDIVIDUALS WITH KIDNEY FAILURE FROM UNFAIR PRACTICES. The amendment to the Social Security Act prohibits differentiation in benefits based on end stage renal disease for individuals covered by a plan or issuer. Patients must be notified of changes to dialysis service benefits, out-of-network access restrictions, or reductions in services. The amendment to the Social Security Act prohibits differentiation in benefits based on end stage renal disease for individuals covered by a plan or issuer. Patients must be notified of changes to dialysis service benefits, out-of-network access restrictions, or reductions in rates paid for out-of-network benefits. Patients must be allowed to continue using their existing provider or facility for at least 24 months following any network changes. Patients must be held harmless from provider network changes that require unreasonable drive time. The amendment to the Social Security Act prohibits differentiation in benefits based on end stage renal disease for individuals covered by a plan or issuer. Changes to dialysis services must not require unreasonable drive time or disrupt the physician-patient relationship. Restrictions on the duration or number of dialysis sessions are not allowed. Benefits cannot be restricted based on a fixed number of treatments per week. Assignment of benefits for services is not required. Out-of-pocket payments for services must apply to Medicare Part C out-of-pocket costs. The amendment to the Social Security Act, effective January 1, 2014, ensures that Medicare Part C out-of-pocket maximums are not used to calculate copayments for dialysis services. Coverage cannot be denied based on third-party payments, and network adequacy standards must be met for these services. TITLE II--SUPPORTING RESEARCH TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO HIGH QUALITY KIDNEY CARE

SEC. 201. UNDERSTANDING THE PROGRESSION OF KIDNEY DISEASE IN MINORITY POPULATIONS.

The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on factors leading to kidney disease and efforts to slow its progression in minority populations.

SEC. 202. RECOMMENDATIONS ON DIALYSIS QUALITY AND CARE MANAGEMENT RESEARCH GAPS. SEC. 202. RECOMMENDATIONS ON DIALYSIS QUALITY AND CARE MANAGEMENT RESEARCH GAPS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress on research gaps for quality and care management metrics for end-stage renal disease patients, including pediatric and home dialysis patients. The report will include recommendations for filling these gaps and prioritizing research. The Comptroller General of the United States will evaluate transportation barriers for dialysis patients leading to non-compliance with Medicare plans. The evaluation will assess costs, missed treatments, and potential transportation solutions. A report will be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for legislation and administrative action based on the study conducted on transportation barriers for dialysis patients. Improving access to Medicare kidney disease education under Title III. The Social Security Act is amended to include a renal dialysis facility with specific personnel requirements. The Social Security Act is amended to include a renal dialysis facility with specific personnel requirements for providing education services to individuals with kidney failure. Amendment to the Social Security Act includes adding stage V to chronic kidney disease and excluding those receiving dialysis services. Effective from January 1, 2013.
